update.description:
(resubmission of pull request #1386)



Fix for #1000. Currently dart just has a single friction coefficient. They use a friction pyramid internally, the parameters haven't yet been exposed.

I also made `SurfaceParams::GetFrictionPyramid` to simplify access to the `FrictionPyramid` data, so that you don't have to explicitly cast the `SurfaceParams` object based on the physics engine. See `physics_friction.cc` for an illustration of much this simplifies things for the user.

I ran a [Jenkins dart build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any_dart4-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/70/) and the friction tests are passing. The other test failures are caused by #1435 and #1409 (fixed in pull request #1412).
update.title: Pass Coulomb surface friction parameters to DART

content.raw: I created #1462 to track the need for a new friction test with multiple collision shapes and friction coefficients per link.

content.raw:
Bullet's friction support is a little hacky right now, in that we are specifying a single friction coefficient per link (see [BulletLink.cc:159](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/8c0503b74a57503cd69bbcaee15479daeec22b58/gazebo/physics/bullet/BulletLink.cc#cl-159).

It's currently looping through all the collision shapes and overwriting the `hackMu[12]` values for each collision. It then sets the link friction after this loop. I need to write a test for multiple collisions with different friction coefficients on a single link.
content.html:
Bullet's friction support is a little hacky right now, in that we are specifying a single friction coefficient per link (see BulletLink.cc:159.

It's currently looping through all the collision shapes and overwriting the hackMu[12] values for each collision. It then sets the link friction after this loop. I need to write a test for multiple collisions with different friction coefficients on a single link.

content.raw: Are these two lines needed? Can you put the `friction->GetMu*` directly in the commented `gzerr` call?
content.html: Are these two lines needed? Can you put the friction->GetMu* directly in the commented gzerr call?
